About meResources

Statistics

In this section I will collect all my posts about statistics.

Sometimes dataviz is not sufficient to understand your data. In this case there’s only one way you can rigorously approach your problem: statistics.
This is a huge field, and it’s quite easy to get lost within it. In the following you will find some material which helped me to clarify my ideas and to face data-related problems.


Have fun!

Stippe

Post list

Introduction
  1. An overview to statistics: What well we talk about
  2. Introduction to Bayesian inference: A little bit more about Bayesian inference
  3. How does MCMC works: Getting an idea of what's happening behind the scenes
  4. Some notation about probability: Notation and conventions
Simple models
  1. Section introduction: Understanding the building blocks
  2. The Beta-Binomial model: Dealing with binary outcomes
  3. The Poisson model: How to describe count data
  4. The Negative Binomial model: An evolution of the Poisson model
  5. Bonus: counting animals in a park: The hypergeometric distribution and the capture-mark-recapture method
  6. The Gaussian model: Handling real-valued data
  7. Multidimensional distributions: Dealing with more than two categories
  8. Mixture models: When your population is made by subpopulations
Bayesian workflow
  1. Introduction to the Bayesian workflow: How to make bayesian inference in practice
  2. Trace inspection: Finding issues in MCMC convergence
  3. Predictive checks: Verifying the predictions of your model
  4. Re-parametrizing your model: Building equivalent models with less numerical issues
  5. Model comparison: How to choose between models
  6. Model comparison, cont.: Cross validation in Bayesian statistics
Regression
  1. Introduction to the linear regression: Including dependence on external variables
  2. Linear regression with binary input: Extending regression to discrete variables
  3. Multi-linear regression: Including many covariates
  4. Robust linear regression: Reducing sensitivity to large deviations
  5. Logistic regression: How to perform regression on binary data
  6. Poisson regression: Regression on count data
Hierarchical models
  1. Hierarchical models: How to implement hierarchies
  2. Hierarchical models and meta-analysis: How hierarchical models can be used to analyze scientific literature
  3. Random models and mixed models: Making inference on subgroups
  4. Leveraging mixed-effect models: When and how to use mixed-effect models
  5. Mixed effects models with more than two levels: When hierarchies become complex
Experiments
  1. The problem solving workflow: A broader view of the data science workflow
  2. Things that could go wrong: If something can go wrong, it probably will
  3. Data collection: Choosing how to collect data
  4. Random sampling: Methods for selecting units from a population
  5. Stratification: Grouping units in a useful way
  6. Design of experiments: An application to the DOE principles
  7. Completely randomized design: When only one factor is relevant
  8. Full factorial design: Handling multiple factors of interest together
  9. Latin square design: Blocking two factors
  10. Crossover design: How to quantify the treatment order effect
  11. Split plot design: Handling hard-to-change factors
  12. Repeated measures: When time is one of the factors
  13. Nested factor: Saving yourself from mis-labelling
Causal inference
  1. Validity: How to weight evidence from a study
  2. Causal inference: When association implies causation
  3. Causal inference and Bayesian networks: When does association imply causation?
  4. Randomized controlled trials: When association implies causation
  5. Instrumental variable regression: Making causal inference without randomization
  6. Difference in difference: Causal inference from 1850
  7. Regression discontinuity design: Introducing an arbitrary threshold to infer causality
Advanced models
  1. Introduction to survival analysis: Estimating waiting times
  2. Application of survival analysis 1: Survival analysis with continuous time
  3. Application of survival analysis with discrete times: Survival analysis with discrete time
  4. Introduction to Extreme Values theory: Describing rare events
  5. Quantile regression: Describing less common events
Time series
  1. Structural time series: Adding other kinds of temporal dependencies
  2. Time series: Taking into account time dependence
  3. Stochastic volatility models: How to quantify volatility
Non-parametric models
  1. Nonparametric models: When your focus in on flexibility
  2. Gaussian processes: How to make the normal distribution infinite dimensional
  3. Gaussian processes regression: Using GPs for flexible regression
  4. Splines: Wisely using piecewise functions
  5. Bayesian Additive Regression Trees: Flexible interpolation with regression trees
  6. Dirichlet Process Mixture Models: Mixture models with variable number of components
Other random thoughts
  1. Application of the Lotka-Volterra model: Testing the predictive power of a scientific model
  2. Differential equations: When your mathematical model cannot be explicitly solved
  3. MRP: The one who guessed US election results
  4. Horseshoe priors: Dealing with multi-collinearity
  5. Directional statistics: Inference for angular variables
  6. Fitting complex models: When the going gets tough
Opinions are mine, mistakes too, and if you find any feel free to report it via mail or via Twitter Bluesky
Most of the material in the statistics section is an adaptation to Python of some pre-existing model.
I have tried to provide the necessary credits, but if you think that a relevant contribution is missing, please let me know.
